semantic_title: Structure and Components of ICD-10-CM: Alphabetic Index and Tabular List
section_path: Section I > A. Conventions > 1. The Alphabetic Index and Tabular List

content.full_text: The ICD-10-CM is divided into the Alphabetic Index, an alphabetical list of terms and their corresponding code, and the Tabular List, a structured list of codes divided into chapters based on body system or condition. The Alphabetic Index consists of the following parts: the Index of Diseases and Injury, the Index of External Causes of Injury, the Table of Neoplasms and the Table of Drugs and Chemicals. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L12-L14)
content.summary: Defines the two main components of ICD-10-CM and the four parts of the Alphabetic Index (Evidence: pg no: 7, L12-L14)
key_concepts: ICD-10-CM has two main components: Alphabetic Index and Tabular List (Evidence: pg no: 7, L12-L13)
Alphabetic Index contains terms with corresponding codes (Evidence: pg no: 7, L13)
Tabular List is structured by chapters based on body systems or conditions (Evidence: pg no: 7, L13-L14)
Alphabetic Index has four distinct parts (Evidence: pg no: 7, L14)

detailed_rules.rule_text: ICD-10-CM is divided into Alphabetic Index and Tabular List (Evidence: pg no: 7, L12-L13)
detailed_rules.explanation: The classification system has two primary components that work together for code assignment (Evidence: pg no: 7, L12-L13)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Alphabetic Index consists of four parts: Index of Diseases and Injury, Index of External Causes of Injury, Table of Neoplasms, and Table of Drugs and Chemicals (Evidence: pg no: 7, L14)
detailed_rules.explanation: The Alphabetic Index is subdivided into specialized sections for different types of conditions and causes (Evidence: pg no: 7, L14)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify the type of condition to determine which part of Alphabetic Index to use
Step 2: Look up the term in the appropriate index section
Step 3: Verify the code in the Tabular List
Step 4: Apply any additional instructions from the Tabular List
related_terminology: Index of External Causes of Injury

references_to.title: Adverse effects, poisoning, underdosing and toxic effects
references_to.explanation: References Table of Drugs and Chemicals usage

coding_scenarios.scenario: Coding a malignant neoplasm of the breast
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify this as a neoplasm condition
Step 2: Use Table of Neoplasms in Alphabetic Index
Step 3: Look up 'breast' and find malignant column
Step 4: Verify code in Tabular List

correct_coding.rationale: Table of Neoplasms is the appropriate section for neoplasm coding (Evidence: pg no: 7, L14)

incorrect_coding.code: Using Index of Diseases and Injury
incorrect_coding.rationale: Would not provide proper neoplasm behavior classification
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not using specialized tables when available

warnings: Must use appropriate section of Alphabetic Index for accurate coding (Evidence: pg no: 7, L14)
best_practices: Always verify codes found in Alphabetic Index by checking Tabular List
Use specialized tables (Neoplasms, Drugs and Chemicals) when applicable
common_mistakes: Using wrong section of Alphabetic Index
Stopping at Alphabetic Index without Tabular List verification
tips: Familiarize yourself with all four parts of the Alphabetic Index
Remember that Tabular List is organized by body system/condition
implementation_notes: Both components must be used together for accurate coding
clinical_context: Different clinical conditions require different index sections
